item.title: Fed holds steady on emergency measures
item.description: US Federal Reserve policymakers ended their two-day meeting on by keeping interest rates steady as expected, but extending the Fed’s $300bn programme to buy Treasury bonds until October

item.title: UBS and US strike tax evasion deal
item.description: Lawyers for UBS and the US government said they had reached a deal to settle the long and bitter battle over access to US client names

item.title: India plans green overhaul with own EPA
item.description: Environmental agency modelled on that of US would implement and monitor standards, says environment minister

item.title: Pequot and chairman face possible SEC charges
item.description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has warned Pequot Capital Management that it is considering filing securities fraud charges against the hedge fund and its chairman, Arthur Samberg, based on 2001 trading in Microsoft stock, Pequot has told investors

item.title: Bank says UK is set for slow recovery
item.description: The Bank of England delivered a more robust forecast for the economy over the rest of this year and into 2010, even as it warned the recovery was likely to be ‘slow and protracted‘

item.title: Obama on drive to tackle healthcare rage
item.description: Barack Obama takes to the road again on Friday to try to push back against the “scare tactics” of those opposing his controversial healthcare reforms amid what some US commentators are describing as the least civil political environment they have witnessed.

item.title: Subdued recovery in global oil demand
item.description: The US summer driving season “seems to have fizzled out before getting started” the International Energy Agency said, striking a cautious tone on prospects for a recovery in global energy demand next year

item.title: BHP sees end to iron ore benchmark
item.description: Chief executive calls for heat to be taken out of traditional round of price-setting talks between ore miners and steelmakers

item.title: US hails win in China trade dispute
item.description: The Obama administration and Hollywood hailed a World Trade Organisation ruling they said would help open up Chinese markets for everything from magazines to film blockbusters as well as curbing intellectual piracy
